Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Taking Sustainable Cements to the Next Level: New Routes to Control and Amplify the Chemical Reactivity of Cementing Phases

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project engineers portland cements having enhanced reactivity, so as to substantially enhance efficiencies associated with the use of cement in concrete. Reactivity amplifications are provoked by manipulating: (1) impurity distributions (i.e., guest ions) and (2) thermal processing (e.g., quenching) routes through cement synthesis. These manipulations induce structural imperfections in cement minerals, and thus act to elevate their reactivity. Reactivity is studied across quantum-to-continuum scales using density functional theory and molecular dynamics calculation, by synthesis of pure cement phases and their solid solutions, and by nanoscale measurements of phase dissolution rates. The investigations are organized for calculation and experiment to interact with each other, and guide the discovery of highly reactive cementing phases through detailed considerations of phase chemistry, properties and processing.

This research places emphasis on reactivity, to produce concretes using a smaller quantity of highly reactive cement, which are performance-equivalent to concretes produced today using larger quantities of traditional cements. Thus, by reducing the use/wastage of cement in concrete, the outcomes of the work conservatively target global cement (and CO2 emissions) savings of around 15%, i.e., around 500 million tons. This is a translational paradigm in reducing cement use, which will radically alter how sustainability is approached from a materials perspective by the construction industry. The project develops graduated training across levels of scientific maturity, from high-school students to post-doctoral scientists. Diversity and high-school engagement platforms at UCLA are leveraged to provide research opportunities to financially disadvantaged minority candidates, while LA-high-school educators and YouTube and Facebook ventures are engaged to incite interest in, and provide growth opportunities to young scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major outcomes (Intellectual Merit): This project has resulted in significant new knowledge related to: (a) understanding how impurities alter the reactivity of cement, (b) the development of new nanoscale tools for analyzing the reactivity of minerals and glasses, (c) the description of a new theory which explains how the reactivity of crystals and glasses is dictated by their atomic architecture, (d) the first demonstrations of how machine learning/big-data analytics can be used to assess the engineering properties of concrete, and (e) the development of new microscopy based-methods  which quantify how oxidation (corrosion) rates are correlated with the solution environment, and the alloy's structure. 

Major outcomes (Broader Impacts): This CAREER award has supported the training of numerous Ph.D. students working across a diversity of topics. Importantly, the nature of training offered has spanned both computational, experimental and hybrid methods. This nature of support has been foundational for training much-needed experts whose scientific and technical contributions will benefit the engineering community. Moreover, the integration of research and teaching has been achieved in coursework. Furthermore, the project has engaged > 2 undergraduates per year in research. These undergraduates have worked closely with the PI and a graduate student mentor to work on focussed topics including: (i) carbonate mineralization, and, (ii) reactivity of silicates. Such engagement has offered a means to develop hands-on skills, and translate high-level research findings to beginning researchers in a non-classroom setting. In addition, the outcomes of this work have been disseminated via: (a) refereed journal publications, (b) presentations at both community-specific, and cross-disciplinary conferences, (c) in patent filings, and (d) presentations to corporations, and industry organizations, and federal agencies. These modes of knowledge dissemination have sought to specifically distribute the learning outcomes both widely and deeply so as to maximize the impact and value of the research.
